A Boolean is a data type that can only have one of two values:
✓ true
✘ false
Think of it like a light switch — it’s either on (true) or off (false). There’s no in-between.
Why Do We Need Booleans?
Booleans are used whenever we want to make decisions in our code.
Imagine asking a question like:
• "Is the user logged in?"
• "Is the temperature above 100?"
• "Is the password correct?"
All these are yes/no questions — which is where Booleans come in handy.

Where Booleans Are Used
Let’s say you’re building a basic login system where a user can either be logged in or not logged in. You want to display different messages based on the login status.
This is a perfect case to use a Boolean — it helps the program decide what to do based on whether the user is logged in.

What’s Happening in the Code?
The user is not logged in, so we set:
boolean isLoggedIn = false;
The program checks this and prints:
"Please log in to continue."
Now we simulate a successful login by changing the value to true:
isLoggedIn = true;
The program again checks if the user is logged in, and this time prints:
"Login successful! Welcome back, user!"
Output of the program:

data.code:
Please log in to continue.
Login successful! Welcome back, user!

data.html:
Coding Tips
Learning about Booleans may seem basic, but it's one of the most important concepts in programming. Nearly every real-world program uses Booleans to make decisions.
Think of Booleans as the brain's yes/no questions for your code. Happy Coding :)
